awd_titl_txt: Race and Rurality in the Pretrial Experience
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. John Eason at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Department of Sociology and The Justice Lab, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the experience of rural pretrial release. The findings from this project will further knowledge about two understudied phenomena: pretrial release and rural criminology. The long-term implication of this work is to reduce harms associated with being charged with a crime by documenting how punitive surveillance is enacted upon people who are legally presumed to be innocent.

When a person is charged with a crime, their first court appearance is in bond court, where a judge assigns a dollar amount and conditions for release. If the accused person can afford their bond, they will pay to await their trial outside of county jail. This increases their chances of a not guilty verdict and more lenient sentencing. Even so, previous research illustrates how pretrial release is rife with carceral surveillance, which prevents people from attending church, obtaining groceries, or holding a stable job, all while they are legally presumed innocent. Criminology studies are largely conducted in urban settings, but scholars have shown that criminal legal contact both occurs in rural settings and functions differently in these settings. In this project, I ask: How does pretrial release differ in rural settings? This project relies on ethnographic observations and in-depth interviews in two adjacent rural counties, which are demographically and culturally similar but differ in one important aspect: commercial bail has been prohibited in one but still operates in the other, allowing for a comparative analysis of bond systems. Ethnographic observations of pretrial hearings will provide information about how state actors determine bail amounts and conditions in both counties. In-depth interviews (30 in each county, totaling 60 interviews) with people currently or recently on pretrial release will provide insight into the lived experience of pretrial surveillance, highlighting its impact on everyday interactions and encounters in rural areas. This knowledge will strengthen the understudied area of rural criminology in a body of literature that largely centers urban experiences. Additionally, by drawing a direct comparison between two otherwise similar rural counties, this study will also contribute an analysis of how certain bond systems influence pretrial surveillance, showing how rural citizens experience pretrial release within both for-profit commercial and state-run bond systems. This project will demonstrate the importance of including all criminalized people in bond reform and other efforts to end mass criminalization. Findings will contribute to public advocacy work being conducted at the local and national levels on the abolition of money bond and the harms of pretrial surveillance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Erin Eife completed data collection and preliminary analysis for the project “Race and Rurality in the Pretrial Experience,” under the auspices of an NSF Fundamental Research Postdoctoral Research Fellowship with her Sponsoring Scientist John Eason. This project utilizes qualitative data to understand the experience of bond court and pretrial release in two rural counties in the Midwest. Specifically, this project is comprised of ethnographic courtroom observations in two courthouses and 39 in-depth interviews with people on pretrial release.

While most research on criminal legal contact takes place in urban settings, scholars have shown that criminal legal contact both occurs in rural settings and functions differently in these settings. For instance, as compared to urban areas, there are fewer resources and heightened visibility for people charged or convicted of a crime in rural geographies. As such, this project asks: How does pretrial release differ in rural settings? Data collection efforts have been tailored to information about how spatial context, race and racism, and type of criminalized behavior influence experiences of surveillance for people on pretrial release. NSF support was used to cover trips to the field site, pay interview respondents and undergraduate research assistants, pay for interview transcription, purchase books and data analysis software, fund conference registration and travel, and other related research expenses.

Data collection has been completed and data analysis is still underway. Preliminary findings have shown that there are important distinctions between bond court and pretrial release in rural settings. In particular, access to due process rights is dependent upon geographic context in somewhat paradoxical ways. For instance, speedy trial is strictly adhered to in rural settings, as opposed to drawn out case trajectories in urban settings. Yet, court-appointed legal representation goes through a rigorous financial eligibility process in rural settings, making it more difficult to access than in urban settings, where eligibility is often assumed. Oftentimes, even if a defendant is eligible for a public defender, one is not present in the courtroom due to the fact that many rural areas are legal deserts. Finally, the presumption of innocence was difficult to realize for those who had direct or family ties to the criminal legal system. This is unique to rural areas, where this familiarity with defendants is much more common when compared to the large populations of urban settings. These initial findings suggest that, in order to fully understand the experience of pretrial release, it is essential to expand the geographic scope of analysis to include rural and suburban contexts, as well.

This project has generated intellectual merit by producing more empirical information about the criminal legal system in rural contexts which are understudied despite the growing knowledge that carceral systems are expanding in these areas. Courtroom ethnographic observations showed the importance of geographic context in how defendants and types of charges are perceived by judges and other court actors. These observations also provide insights into how bond amount and type and pretrial release conditions are assigned. Interviews with people on pretrial release unveiled critical information about the barriers associated with attending court and/or abiding by release conditions, including essential information about the role that geographic and spatial context play. Findings will make important contributions to literature on rural criminology, sociology of punishment, and poverty governance.

This research also has broader impacts for society. Undergraduate research assistants (RAs) from local rural universities have had the opportunity to engage in research and have learned important skills, such as how to take ethnographic fieldnotes, recruit for interviews, and clean transcripts. Several RAs have gone onto relevant graduate school programs or are currently preparing applications for graduate school. Preliminary findings have been presented at one academic conference and the findings from this project will continue to be shared at academic conferences, as well as in peer-reviewed journals and in formats outside of academia, such as social media or public reports. The findings from this project will place an emphasis on the importance of including all people with pending charges, regardless of spatial context, when considering the harsh impact of pretrial surveillance or considering how to improve due process through bond reform efforts.
